q: The ovulatory period corresponds to – (TN 90)
explanation: Ovulation usually occurs about 14 days before the next menstruation.

q: Gonadotrophin is a – (JIPMER 92)
explanation: FSH and LH are glycoprotein hormones.

q: Maximum function of corpus luteum occurs – (JIPMER 93)
explanation: Corpus luteum reaches peak function about 8–9 days after ovulation.

q: The probable source of relaxin is – (JIPMER 91, DNB 89)
explanation: Relaxin is secreted mainly by the corpus luteum of the ovary.

q: Gonadotropins are – (JIPMER 78, Delhi 90)
explanation: FSH and LH are glycoproteins.

q: Ovulation occurs – (Kerala 94)
explanation: Ovulation occurs about 14 days before the next menstrual period.

q: In the absence of fertilization and implantation the corpus luteum persists for – (AP 95)
explanation: Corpus luteum persists for about 12–14 days without pregnancy.

q: False statement regarding hormone status in menopausal women is – (MAHE 98)
explanation: FSH levels are increased, not decreased, after menopause.

q: FSH secretion is stimulated by – (MAHE 98)
explanation: FSH secretion is stimulated by GnRH (LHRH).

q: LH surge precedes ovulation by – (MAHE 98)
explanation: Ovulation occurs approximately 24 hours after the LH surge.

q: Corpus luteum functions maximally without an implantation for – days (PGI 2000)
explanation: Maximum function occurs around day 9 post-ovulation.

q: Hot flushes in postmenopausal women are best treated with which of the following – (AJ 2002)
explanation: Estrogen therapy is most effective for hot flushes.

q: Average age range of attaining menopause is – (TN 03)
explanation: Menopause usually occurs between 45–55 years.

q: Cornification Index is maximum in – (TN 03)
explanation: Cornification index peaks during estrogen dominance.

q: Endometrial biopsy is done in which phase of menstrual cycle –
explanation: Biopsy is ideally done in the late secretory phase.

q: Sertoli cells have receptors for – (AI 04)
explanation: Sertoli cells have FSH receptors.

q: Inhibin inhibits the secretion of which hormone – (TN 04)
explanation: Inhibin specifically inhibits FSH secretion.

q: Primary oocyte remains in ovary in which stage – (SGPGI 05)
explanation: Primary oocyte remains arrested in prophase I.

q: In a young female of reproductive age with regular menstrual cycles of 28 days ovulation occurs around 14th day of periods. When is the first polar body extruded – (AIIMS May 05)
explanation: First polar body is extruded just before ovulation.

q: After how many days of ovulation embryo implantation occurs – (AIIMS 06)
explanation: Implantation occurs around 7–9 days after ovulation.

q: The sensitivity of the uterine musculature is – (AIIMS 06)
options: Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone
explanation: Estrogen increases and progesterone decreases uterine sensitivity.

q: In those mammals which are seasonal breeder, the females are receptive only once a year; the cycle is termed as – (AIIMS 06)
explanation: Seasonal breeders exhibit estrous cycles.

q: Corkscrew shaped endometrial glands is seen in – (APPG 06)
explanation: Corkscrew glands are characteristic of late secretory phase.

q: Following are the features of inhibin except – (Karn pgmee 06)
options: Increased secretion of inhibin occurs in polycystic ovarian disease
explanation: Inhibin inhibits, not stimulates, FSH secretion.

q: Source of progesterone during normal menstrual cycle – (MAHE 07)
explanation: Progesterone is secreted by the corpus luteum.

q: The best predictor of ovulation is – (Corned 08)
explanation: LH surge onset best predicts ovulation.

q: Which of the following is the earliest change in the endometrium after ovulation – (UPSC 1108)
options: Secretion in the lumina of the endometrial glands
Stromal cells become oedematous, enlarged and polyhedral in shape
explanation: Subnuclear vacuolation is the earliest post-ovulatory change.

q: Ovary secretes – (UP 08)
explanation: Ovary secretes estrogen, progesterone and small amounts of androgens.

q: Ovulation occurs – (UP 08)
explanation: Ovulation occurs about 14 days before the next menstruation.

q: Endometrial biopsy is done at – (UP 08)
explanation: Endometrial biopsy is done in the premenstrual (late secretory) phase.

q: Naturally occurring estrogens are – (PGI Dec 08)
explanation: Naturally occurring estrogens are estrone, estradiol and estriol.

q: Characteristics of the fertile phase of the menstrual cycle include all of the following except – (COMED 09)
explanation: Progesterone production is characteristic of the luteal phase, not the fertile phase.

q: The “fern pattern” of cervical mucus seen in the first half of menstrual cycle is because of – (UPSC II 09)
explanation: High sodium chloride content causes the fern pattern.

q: After how many hours of LH surge does the ovulation occur? (UPSC II 09)
explanation: Ovulation occurs about 12–36 hours after LH surge.

q: True about hCG – (PGI June 09)
options: Value reach maximum level at 20 wk of pregnancy
Its secretion starts after 2 day of ovulation
explanation: hCG prevents involution of corpus luteum.

q: True statement regarding oogenesis is/are – (PGI May 10)
options: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of II nd meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in Metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrests in Metaphase of II nd meiotic division
1st polar body is extruded during 1st meiotic division of primary oocytes
explanation: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase I; secondary oocyte in metaphase II; first polar body is extruded during meiosis I.

q: True statement regarding implantation –
explanation: Implantation occurs in blastocyst stage around day 5–7 after ovulation.

q: True about hCG – (PGI Nov 10)
options: α subunit identical to LH, FSH & TSH
Max. level seen at 60–70 days of gestation
Detected in serum and urine 8–9 days after ovulation
explanation: hCG has identical α subunit, peaks at 8–10 weeks, and is detected early in pregnancy.

q: Which of the following is seen in the ovulatory phase – (AIIMS May 11)
options: Stimulation of continuation of reduction division of oocytes
FSH increases steroid synthesis in granulosa cells
Activin causes FSH to act on granulosa cells
explanation: Activin enhances FSH action on granulosa cells.

q: The peak level of serum LH (ng/ml) required for ovulation – (Karn 11)
explanation: Minimum LH peak of about 25 ng/ml is required for ovulation.

q: During a normal pregnancy, the changes occurring in the urinary tract include the following except – (UPSC II 11)
options: Increase in the glomerular filtration rate
Elevation and thickening of the trigone
Hypertonicity of the ureteric smooth muscle
explanation: Ureteric smooth muscle becomes hypotonic, not hypertonic, in pregnancy.

q: Fertilization occurs in – (JIPMER 11)
explanation: Fertilization normally occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.
